III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 2/13/25, a youth walked away from the facility and staff did not
try to stop the youth. The youth was wearing a t-shirt and was
away for two hours. Last night, the youth left the facility without a
coat. There are concerns regarding supervision.
Investigation Phone messages were left with and received from
Complainant on 2/14/25 and 2/20/24; no additional information
was provided by Complainant.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on February 19, 2025. CA reported Youth D will
frequently leave the facility if she does not get her own way. CA
stated if the facility has enough staff to maintain ratio one staff will
follow Youth D but if the facility does not have extra staff, they will
not follow Youth D. CA described on 2/13/25 the facility did not
have extra staff as the extra staff was in the community with youth
who were at the waterpark for an outing. CA reported if a staff
would have followed Youth D on 2/13/2025 the facility would have
been out of ratio.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on February
19, 2025. Staff 1 described Youth D being upset because she
could not pick the TV station, so Youth D went upstairs to her
bedroom. Staff 1 stated Youth D was escalated saying she was
going to leave the facility. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 talked with
Youth D attempting to de-escalate Youth D and offered many
other options rather than leaving the facility. Staff 1 denied Youth
A made any self-harm statements when she left the facility. Staff
1 stated if the facility has extra staff a staff will follow Youth D
when she leaves but this day if a staff would have left the facility,
the facility would have been out of ratio. Staff 1 reported Youth D
left the facility and law enforcement was contacted.
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C were interviewed face to face
at the facility, separately, on February 19, 2025. All three youth
reported if a youth leaves the facility and there are enough staff for
2

the facility to maintain ratio a staff will follow the youth. Youth A
described staff as, “getting on my nerves, they [staff] watch us so
much.” Youth B and Youth C both stated staff always watch the
youth and if a youth leaves staff call the police.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on February 20, 2025.
Staff 2 described Youth D being upset and saying she was “gonna
cause a scene.” Staff 2 reported she attempted to de-escalate
Youth D by offering to play music, play with Legos, color and other
activities to take Youth D’s mind off being upset. Staff 2 stated
Youth D went upstairs to Youth D’s room, grabbed a pair of socks
and stated she was leaving the facility. Staff 2 reported if she
would have followed Youth D the facility would have been out of
ratio. Staff 2 stated half of the youth were off campus at a
waterpark so there was not an extra staff on shift. Staff 2 reported
there have been times she followed a youth when the youth left
the house because there were enough staff to maintain ratio.
Staff 2 denied Youth D making any self-harm statements when
leaving the facility. Staff 2 stated Staff 1 called law enforcement to
report Youth D AWOL.
Documents Reviewed:
• Interview notes from Licensing Consultant’s interview with
Youth D at Forest View Inpatient Hospital on 2/27/25.
“[Youth D] really like staying at New Hope, it is the best
facility that she has stayed at. When asked to explain more
she reported that she gets to go out on a lot of outings and
gets to go to school off grounds. She confirmed it is an
open facility. She reported that the staff are really nice
there. I asked about the AWOL incident from 2/13. She
reported that staff were watching her but when they turned
their head, she left the building. She could not remember
what staff was working. She reported that staff watched
her but once she hit the driveway, they cannot see her.
She reported staff will not restrain a youth if they run away.
She reported staff only restrain if the youth is a harm to
themselves or others. [Youth D] reported that staff
supervise really well but they can’t chase a kid when they
run because they have to stay in ratio. I asked about [Staff
1] and she reported that she is a really nice staff and does
a great job with the youth. Noted no concerns with
supervision. [Youth D] wants to go back to New Hope and
has a plan to not awol any longer.”
• Incident Report dated 2/13/2025 for Youth D. Incident
report consistent with staff and youth interviews. Incident
3

report documented date/time worker, Law enforcement,
parent/guardian, and DCWL was notified of AWOL.
• Email from Foster Care Worker dated 2/19/2025 regarding
Youth D’s placement at the facility. “[Youth D] has
struggled significantly while at New Hope. They have been
very proactive in their communication with me regarding
her struggles as well as involved in planning and trying to
find a way to keep [Youth D] safe from her own decisions. I
would never expect them to jeopardize their staffing ratio in
the home when [Youth D] is choosing to leave. They are
also limited in what they are able to do to prevent her from
leaving in the first place.”
• New Hope Youth Center Youth Supervision, Movement
and Checks Policy. Policy states, “Staff shall ensure that
appropriate supervision of the youth is maintained at all
times. Staff shall provide effective positioning for optimal
sight and sound supervision of youth. Staff shall
communicate with youth and co-workers effectively to
ensure expectations are clearly defined. The Facility
Administrator shall ensure that the program provides a
staffing pattern that promotes “line of sight” supervision of
youth at all times. Scheduling shall ensure that the
program meets all contractual and mandated guidelines for
required ratios and the supervision of youth.”
• New Hope Youth Center Incident Reporting Policy. The
policy states if a youth leaves without permission they
need to contact law enforcement.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, staff provided adequate supervision of Youth D and
attempted to de-escalate Youth D to persuade her not to leave the
facility. The facility is an open non-secure program.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
